name: ARCHIVE REISSUE SUEDE DOUBLE POCKET JACKET
rationale: Suede is an anti-preference material, and at $650 for a conventional button-front silhouette with no textural embellishment, this directly conflicts with both the suede rejection pattern and the rule against paying premiums for conventional forms.

name: QUILTED VELVET VEST
rationale: Sleeveless vest is an explicitly rejected silhouette. Despite the quilted velvet texture and snap buttons providing some visual interest, vests are a firm anti-preference.

name: REVERSIBLE COTTON CAR COAT
rationale: Long coat silhouette falling well below mid-thigh directly conflicts with the length anti-preference. While the reversible gingham lining adds material interest, the long, single-material cotton construction fails on multiple strong preferences.

name: TEXTURED SUEDE JACKET
rationale: Suede is an anti-preference material, but this piece has offsetting positives: cropped hip-length silhouette, oversized/relaxed fit, warm cognac-brown color, and distinctive metal toggle/clasp hardware providing artisanal detail. The hardware is genuinely interesting but suede at $700 remains a significant conflict.

name: LIGHTWEIGHT UTILITY JACKET
rationale: Tie-front/belted closure is an anti-preference, the olive-khaki color is somewhat washed out, and the plain single-material cotton construction has no textural complexity. The fitted-waist silhouette also conflicts with the preference for relaxed/oversized fit.

name: ITALIAN WOOL-BLEND TOP COAT
rationale: Long coat falling well below mid-thigh in cool-toned charcoal grey with plain, single-material wool construction. Conflicts with length, color (cool tones avoided), and textural complexity preferences simultaneously.

name: ITALIAN WOOL-CASHMERE WRAP COAT
rationale: Full-length black wrap coat with open-front construction hits multiple anti-preferences: below mid-thigh length, plain single-material construction, and open/tie-front closure. A premium price for a completely conventional long coat form.

name: ITALIAN WOOL-CASHMERE WRAP COAT
rationale: Full-length camel wrap coat with open-front closure. Same silhouette issues as BR_007: too long, open-front closure, plain single-material construction with no textural interest despite the warm camel color.

name: DISTRESSED LEATHER FLIGHT JACKET
rationale: Strong bomber/flight jacket silhouette with cropped length, ribbed cuffs and hem, oversized fit, and dark earth-tone color. The distressed leather finish and shearling collar provide mixed-material textural complexity. Misses Tier 1 because the embellishment is more inherent to the aviator form than a distinctive decorative element, and $698 is high for what is ultimately a fairly classic flight jacket shape.

name: FUZZY ITALIAN WOOL-BLEND TOP COAT
rationale: Long coat with blanket-stitch trim provides genuine artisanal detailing, but the silhouette falls well below mid-thigh which is a strong anti-preference. The warm russet-brown color is on-palette and the whip-stitch edge detail is craft-forward, but the length disqualifies it from higher tiers.

name: HERITAGE SUEDE JACKET
rationale: Suede material in camel/tan is an anti-preference, and the jacket appears to be a plain, unadorned single-material suede shirt-jacket construction. At $598 this is a premium price for a conventional suede form with no embellishment or textural complexity.

name: DOUBLE-FACED TOP COAT
rationale: Long dark olive coat falling well below mid-thigh in a plain, single-material wool construction. While the double-faced nature means there is a contrasting brown undercollar, the silhouette length and lack of textural complexity are decisive negatives.

name: ITALIAN JACQUARD OVERCOAT
rationale: The jacquard pattern provides genuine textural complexity with a brown and blue woven check, and the velvet collar and pocket trim introduce mixed-material interest. However, the long overcoat silhouette falling below mid-thigh conflicts with the length anti-preference, preventing a higher tier despite the textural strengths.

name: ITALIAN WOOL-CASHMERE WRAP COAT
rationale: Full-length bright blue wrap coat in a single plain material. Conflicts with anti-preferences on length (well below mid-thigh), color (bright primary blue is avoided), plain construction, and the open-front wrap closure.

name: DOUBLE-FACED TOP COAT
rationale: Long black top coat falling well below mid-thigh in plain, single-material wool construction. Hits length and textural anti-preferences. Despite the double-faced feature, the overall appearance is a conventional minimalist long coat.

name: OVERSIZED DISTRESSED LEATHER BOMBER JACKET
rationale: Strong alignment with bomber silhouette preference: cropped, oversized fit, zip-front, ribbed cuffs and hem. The deep olive/dark green leather is within the earth-tone palette. The distressed leather finish adds textural character. Falls short of Tier 1 because the bomber lacks a distinctive decorative embellishment beyond the distressing, which is inherent to the material treatment rather than applied surface design.

name: ITALIAN WOOL-BLEND TOP COAT
rationale: Long navy top coat falling below mid-thigh in a plain, single-material construction. Conflicts with length, cool-tone navy color, and lack of textural complexity. A conventional coat form at a premium price.

name: DOUBLE-FACED TOP COAT
rationale: Long camel-striped top coat well below mid-thigh. While the tonal stripe pattern adds some visual interest and the camel color is within the warm palette, the long coat silhouette is a firm anti-preference and the construction remains a plain single-material wool.

name: FLORAL QUILTED PARKA
rationale: Hits several preference notes: oversized relaxed fit, cropped to hip length, dark olive/floral print provides surface-level design interest, quilted construction adds textural dimension, zip-front closure, and the price is within the core $100-$200 range. The dark floral on olive reads as warm earth-tone camouflage rather than bright. Misses Tier 1 because the parka silhouette is not quite bomber-adjacent and the floral could read as boho to this user.

name: DOUBLE-FACED TOP COAT
rationale: Long navy double-faced top coat with contrasting brown collar lining, falling well below mid-thigh. Despite the double-faced contrast detail and warm palette on the reverse, the long coat silhouette is a decisive anti-preference.

name: SLIM EVERYWHERE PONTE BLAZER
rationale: Slim, fitted, body-skimming ponte blazer in olive is a traditional tailored/corporate blazer silhouette in a single material with no textural complexity. Conflicts with anti-preferences for fitted silhouettes, traditional tailored blazers, and plain single-material construction.

name: DOUBLE-FACED TOP COAT
rationale: Long orange/coral-red top coat falling below mid-thigh. While it has some visual punch in the warm color and the double-faced construction, the color leans toward a bright primary tone rather than the dark/warm earth tones preferred, and the long coat silhouette is a firm anti-preference.

name: SHORT REVERSIBLE COTTON CAR COAT
rationale: The shorter length (hip to mid-thigh) is closer to the preferred range and the reversible feature introduces material interest. However, the cream/ivory color without heavy darker contrast elements, plain cotton construction, and somewhat conventional button-front car coat form provide limited alignment with the profile.

name: QUILTED CHENILLE & CANVAS FIELD JACKET
rationale: Mixed-material construction (quilted chenille + canvas) with visible diamond-quilt pattern aligns with the textural complexity preference. The warm cognac/camel color is on-palette and the hip-length cropped silhouette fits. However, suede-like chenille material is a concern, the field jacket silhouette is not bomber-adjacent, and the overall look leans more traditional country than craft-forward modernist.

name: OVERSIZED TWILL BLAZER
rationale: Black oversized blazer in a plain single-material twill construction. While the oversized fit and black color align, the traditional blazer silhouette in a plain, texturally flat material directly matches the anti-preference for corporate/minimalist single-material blazers.

name: HERITAGE SUEDE JACKET
rationale: Light tan/beige suede jacket in a plain, unadorned single-material construction. Suede is an anti-preference material, the light beige color is washed-out rather than dark/warm, and at $600 there is no design novelty to justify the premium. Conflicts on multiple fronts.

name: DOUBLE-FACED TOP COAT
rationale: Long emerald green top coat falling well below mid-thigh in a single-material wool construction. While green is closer to earth tones, the bright jewel-tone green is not within the preferred dark/warm palette, and the long coat silhouette is a decisive anti-preference.

name: ITALIAN MELTON WOOL-BLEND PEACOAT
rationale: Cropped, oversized yellow peacoat with some alignment on silhouette (cropped, relaxed fit, double-breasted with volume). However, the bright yellow color is a strong conflict with the dark/warm earth-tone palette preference, and the plain single-material construction lacks textural complexity.

name: BARN COAT
rationale: Dark indigo denim barn coat at hip length with metal toggle/clasp hardware providing artisanal-style closure detail. The relaxed fit and dark color have some alignment, but denim is a single material without textural complexity, and the barn coat form is not bomber-adjacent. The toggle closures add character but the overall piece reads more workwear-basic than craft-forward.

name: SLIM CITY STRETCH BLAZER
rationale: Fitted, slim olive blazer in a plain single-material stretch fabric. This is the exact archetype of the anti-preference: a traditional tailored/corporate blazer in a single material with no textural complexity, fitted silhouette, and minimalist styling.

name: DOUBLE-FACED SHORT JACKET WITH BLANKET STITCH
rationale: Strong alignment on multiple preference axes: cropped hip-length silhouette, oversized/boxy relaxed fit, prominent blanket-stitch detailing providing artisanal craft interest, double-faced construction for material mixing. The blanket stitch satisfies the embellishment requirement. Falls short of Tier 1 because the warm coral/salmon color is not within the preferred dark earth-tone palette and leans toward the bright/warm side rather than dark.

name: SLIM ITALIAN WOOL BLAZER
rationale: Slim, fitted dark navy wool blazer is the prototypical anti-preference item: a traditional tailored/corporate blazer in a single material with fitted silhouette, cool navy color, and no textural complexity or embellishment. Styled with a suit further reinforces the corporate aesthetic.

name: CLASSIC COTTON TRENCH COAT
rationale: Classic trench coat silhouette in olive cotton falling well below mid-thigh. Trench coats are explicitly listed as an anti-preference silhouette, and the belted, button-front styling with plain single-material cotton construction conflicts on every major preference dimension.
